version there are two updates where the first one would be installed with
the first run and the second with the second run.

While Jake is busy with his pet project* we can use jitpack.io to get
binaries:
buildscript {
    repositories {
        jcenter()
        maven { url 'https://jitpack.io' }
    }
    dependencies {
        classpath 'com.android.tools.build:gradle:1.2.3'
        classpath 'com.github.JakeWharton:sdk-manager-plugin:0ce4cdf08009d79223850a59959d9d6e774d0f77'
    }
}
Where 0ce4cdf08009d79223850a59959d9d6e774d0f77 is the HEAD commit SHA.
It's even better then -SNAPSHOT releases because we can fix source state
by commit.

joebowbeer:
Also reported as #47 as well as #70.
And now reported as Issue 212309 in Android Tools.
One workaround is to execute gradle twice, once to throw away, for example:
./gradlew dependencies || true
./gradlew assembleDebug
. I suspect that ./gradlew --refresh-dependencies works in the same way that adding any extra ./gradlew invocation works. In other words, I doubt it works any better than:
./gradlew clean || true
./gradlew assembleDebug
or
./gradlew dependencies || true
./gradlew clean assembleDebug

kofalt:
Having just tackled this exact problem, the below may be of interest.
Simply add this to your CI bash script.
``` bash
64-bit Linux needs some packages to execute Android tools
if [ uname == 'Linux' ] && [ uname -m = x86_64 ]; then
    echo "Installing Linux 64-bit packages"
    sudo apt-get update -qq
    sudo apt-get install -qq --force-yes libgd2-xpm ia32-libs ia32-libs-multiarch > /dev/null
fi
```
. Having just tackled this exact problem, the below may be of interest.
Simply add this to your CI bash script.
``` bash
64-bit Linux needs some packages to execute Android tools
if [ uname == 'Linux' ] && [ uname -m = x86_64 ]; then
    echo "Installing Linux 64-bit packages"
    sudo apt-get update -qq
    sudo apt-get install -qq --force-yes libgd2-xpm ia32-libs ia32-libs-multiarch > /dev/null
fi
```

JaredBanyard:
Yeah v20 sdk and support libs seem to not get pulled
. @dodgex Updating the local SDK isn't using the sdkmanager.  It just means whatever isn't found in the dynamically downloaded sdkmanager components, is pulled from the local SDK.  This won't work if you have a workstation or Jenkins server running builds without an SDK installation at all.  The beauty of this tool was being able to get rid of the SDK completely and download only the required components on a piecemeal basis.
. @dodgex Actually no. It downloads every required component of the SDK into the project's workspace.  The advantage is never having to wonder if the local SDK has the required components to build a given project.  Be it on your computer, a remote build server, or a sales guy trying to run the app in a simulator.
Try removing the v20 requirements and deleting some portion of your SDK.  It will use it's dynamically downloaded components, not the SDK.  In your case, the IDE has a reference to your local SDK and can see the missing components not downloaded in sdkmanager for v20, and uses those.
I had this same thing working until I pushed to our Jenkins build server that doesn't have an SDK installation and was just using sdkmanager to download what it needed.  My local SDK had the v20 stuff, and my local IDE was able to utilize those. But, when the code was pulled down on Jenkins, sdkmanager failed to get the v20 stuff, and with no local SDK with v20 stuff, the builds failed.
So you either have to do a hybrid solution like you are doing and have a second SDK instance to reference for the missing sdkmanager modules, or just pull sdkmanager for now and use purely local SDK components.
. @dodgex Ah okay you are right.  So either way, you are still taking a hybrid approach and manually updating sdkmanager's sdk.  This will keep you going until a fix can be found.  Programmatically running the update on the sdkmanager's sdk instance seems to be counter to it's whole design philosophy of only grabbing what you need, has anybody actually tracked down the specific issue inside the Groovy code?
. @dodgex I see the complication, trying to know what the sdk tools version number is before they are out or running a blind "update all" to SDK Tools (and maybe Platform Tools?)  Yeah I see no real harm in making sure the SDK Tools are always at the latest.

. @JaredBanyard has anybody actually tracked down the specific issue inside the Groovy code? yes. i did. ;)
if this plugins does not find an installed sdk (via ANDROID_HOME environment variable or in ~/.android-sdk) it downloads the sdk files and extracts them to ~/-android-sdk. the problem is that this downloaded sdk is outdated (there is a commit to download the newer sdk version but that is not yet released). this outdated sdk is not able to get the v20 dependencies mentioned in this issue. and as the sdk is not able to get them, the sdkmanager is unable to get them too, as it calls the android sdk tools to load the dependencies.
therefore the fix would be: the sdkmanager should make sure that the Android SDK Tools are up to date

echo "y" | ~/.android-sdk/tools/android update sdk -u --filter tools

. Update: the rabbit hole is much deeper than first thought:
I forked a version of the plugin, figured out how to add a user-agent string and how to build it into my android gradle config. When I ran it, I found that the redirecting was still happening. I eventually ended up uploading a copy of the binary on cloudfiles and hacking the script to download from there. That works fine, but the android update xml files (like these: https://dl-ssl.google.com/android/repository/repository-10.xml) are also from the same URL, and also redirect.
I've checked my IP and it doesn't seem to be blacklisted, so I'm not sure what the issue is. I thought about setting up a http proxy and chucking it on heroku, but the android update xml files are on a https url, so I don't believe I can do that...
. I'm pretty sure it's something to do with the digital ocean server I was running on - I've ran my Ansible config on a linode box and all is well. I've sent a Support ticket to DO to see what's going on on their end - I'll let you know if they can't find a fault on their end.
. So DO said that they think there isn't a problem on their end, although they admit that they can replicate their problem on their London Datacenter. Apparently their other Datacenters aren't affected though. My guess is their IP range has been banned for someone else's nefarious activity. I'll stick with Linode for the time being!

marcin-kozinski:
I think the plugin just checks if the ANDROID_HOME directory exists and if it does, then it assumes that SDK is downloaded. So if you have an empty dir under ANDROID_HOME it will assume SDK is downloaded and proceeds with the next step. If that's the case, just remove the dir and it should start to work.
. :thumbsup:

Manabu-GT:
I was having the same issue.
The workaround I did was to add
./gradlew -refresh-dependencies
before
./gradlew clean assembleDebug -PdisablePreDex
Depending on your set up, doing "-refresh-dependencies" every time takes long time and might not be an acceptable workaround.
"The --refresh-dependencies option tells Gradle to ignore all cached entries for resolved modules and artifacts. A fresh resolve will be performed against all configured repositories, with dynamic versions recalculated, modules refreshed, and artifacts downloaded." quoted from Gradle manual.

D:\TestApplication>gradlew assemble
Download https://jitpack.io/com/github/plastiv/sdk-manager-plugin/b04aea1cddf87e78db9a4372794d678f9e568c48/sdk-manager-p
lugin-b04aea1cddf87e78db9a4372794d678f9e568c48.pom
Download https://jitpack.io/com/github/plastiv/sdk-manager-plugin/b04aea1cddf87e78db9a4372794d678f9e568c48/sdk-manager-p
lugin-b04aea1cddf87e78db9a4372794d678f9e568c48.jar
FAILURE: Build failed with an exception.
* What went wrong:
A problem occurred configuring project ':app'.
> failed to find Build Tools revision 23.0.2
. I ended up with the following script (on linux) to update the tools and automatically accept license
(while :
do
  echo 'y'
  sleep 10
done) | ~/.android-sdk/tools/android update sdk -u -a -t "build-tools-23.0.2"
which works. Then I noticed that the plugin started working now, so no need for the script anymore.
I think it works now because instead of fetching URL
https://dl-ssl.google.com/android/repository/repository-10.xml
the script fetches the following URL, which includes the build tools.
https://dl.google.com/android/repository/repository-11.xml
. I've found the cause after having to wipe Android Sdk and download it again. For some reason when the plugin downloads the Android Sdk, it does not download the latest "SDK Tools" (which at the time of writing are 24.4.1. That results in using the following repository to download the build tools
https://dl-ssl.google.com/android/repository/repository-10.xml
But the repository is older and build tools 23.0.2 are not contained in it. If "SDK Tools" are updated manually (by running  , for example) then the latest repository is used (https://dl.google.com/android/repository/repository-11.xml), in which the lastest build tools are contained. So the real problem is that the plugin does not download the latest "SDK tools" at first time.
